children: A 76-year-old woman has chronic pain in both thumbs.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is osteoarthritis. This patient demonstrates the characteristic prominence and squaring of osteoarthritis involving the thumb base due to osteophyte formation and subluxation at the first carpometacarpal joint. The joints most commonly involved in osteoarthritis are weight-bearing joints. Affected nonâ€“weight-bearing joints in the hand typically include the first carpometacarpal, distal interphalangeal (DIP), and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints. Findings on physical examination typically include bony enlargement and malalignment. Heberden and/or Bouchard nodes (ossified growths at the medial and dorsolateral aspects of the DIP or PIP joints, respectively) may be present.
